text: March 1988 and more than 3,000 civilians
were killed when Iraqi warplanes dropped
nerve gas on the town of Halabja the
bodies which litter this town were those
of people who ran out of their houses to
try to escape the gas two years later
and then president of Iraq Saddam
Hussein Nord a surprise invasion of
Kuwait a huge military campaign led by
the u.s. forced him to back down after
the ceasefire there were economic
sanctions and UN inspectors appointed to
oversee the destruction of chemical
weapons but Saddam Hussein didn't play
along and those inspectors soon left the
country then there was 911 within days
George W Bush then US president / told
his generals to plan for a possible war
in Iraq states like these and their
terrorist allies constitute an axis of
evil the White House repeatedly tries to
connect Iraq to the 9/11 attacks though
those links later proved false Bush then
hosted Prime Minister Tony Blair in
Texas Blaz critics say it was at this
point he secretly agreed to go to war he
denies that then President Bush went
before the UN to make his case for
disarming Iraq by force the British
government published his own dossier
saying that Iraq had weapons of mass
destruction that could be ready in 45
minutes the intelligence picture they
pink is one accumulated over the last
four years
it is extensive detailed and
authoritative the government later
admitted that intelligence was faulty
and the 45-minute claim was wrong by
November weapons inspectors have been
allowed back but Saddam Hussein was
thought to be stalling after one last
summit an ultimatum was given Saddam
Hussein and his sons must leave Iraq
within 48 hours their refusal to do so
will result in military conflict
the conflict was over quickly or so it
seemed
then came the aftermath it started with
looting it quickly became an organized
insurgency Saddam Hussein was captured
and executed but that didn't stop the
violence pictures emerged - showing the
abuse of Iraqi prisoners by American
troops our country had an obligation to
treat them right we didn't that was
wrong
violence between Shia and Sunni Muslims
intensified the murder rate in Baghdad
tripled the u.s. solution was the surge
an extra 20,000 troops the violence did
appear to ease the number of bombings
fell in April 2009 the UK ended combat
operations 179 British troops had lost
their lives the u.s. withdrew two years
later now rights is not a perfect place
but we're leaving behind a sovereign
stable and self-reliant Iraq since the
start of the conflict is thought a
hundred and seventy-nine thousand
civilians and at least 40,000 military
personnel may have lost their lives
successive Iraqi governments have
struggled to maintain order so-called
Islamic state has taken control of
Suede's of the country including the
second city Mosul as of today attacks
continue across Iraq
